epidemiology: Most common joint disorder, especially in elderly. Affects >10% of men and >13% of women above 60.
treatment_protocol: Start with conservative measures → escalate to surgery if severe

epidemiology: Autoimmune chronic inflammatory disorder. Affects 0.5–1% of population. Women > men (3:1).
treatment_protocol: Early DMARDs → Biologics if needed → Joint replacement in advanced cases

epidemiology: Systemic skeletal disorder affecting >200 million people globally. Common in postmenopausal women.

timeline.symptom: Back pain due to vertebral fracture

treatment_protocol: Diagnose with DEXA → Treat with antiresorptives → Monitor BMD every 1–2 yrs

epidemiology: Occurs in adolescents, often obese boys. Incidence ~10 per 100,000. Can be bilateral.
treatment_protocol: Urgent surgical fixation → Monitor for contralateral involvement

epidemiology: Common sports injury in males aged 30–50. Often during sudden push-off.
treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Confirm with US → Surgery or conservative depending on age/activity

epidemiology: Common sports-related injury, especially in athletes in pivoting sports like football and basketball. Higher incidence in females.
treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → MRI confirmation → Early rehab → Surgery for active patients

epidemiology: Common cause of shoulder pain in older adults and overhead athletes. Incidence increases with age.
treatment_protocol: MRI diagnosis → PT + NSAIDs → Surgery if no improvement

epidemiology: Abnormal development of the hip joint in infants. More common in females and breech births.
treatment_protocol: Screen at birth → Harness if <6 months → Surgery if unresponsive

epidemiology: Idiopathic avascular necrosis of femoral head in children aged 4–10. Males more affected.

timeline.symptom: Reduced hip abduction and internal rotation

treatment_protocol: Early detection → Conservative initially → Surgery if progressive deformity

epidemiology: Fibromatosis of palmar fascia, most common in northern European men >40. Progressive hand deformity.
treatment_protocol: Assess contracture severity → Try injections → Surgery for functional impairment

epidemiology: Common high-energy trauma injury in young adults, and low-energy falls in the elderly with osteoporosis.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → X-ray → Surgical fixation → Rehab

epidemiology: Common in young athletes, especially females, often caused by twisting injury.

important: MRI to assess MPFL and cartilage

treatment_protocol: Reduce → Immobilize → PT → Surgery if unstable

epidemiology: Common fracture, especially in children and athletes. Midshaft is the most frequent location.

additional: CT if displaced or medial fracture

definitive: ORIF if displaced or high-demand patient

treatment_protocol: X-ray → Conservative if non-displaced → ORIF if needed

epidemiology: Most common cause of heel pain. Seen in runners, overweight individuals, and those with flat feet.
treatment_protocol: Conservative → Steroid injection → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Crystal-induced arthritis from monosodium urate. More common in middle-aged men. Incidence rising globally.
treatment_protocol: Treat acute attack → Maintain uric acid <6 mg/dL chronically

epidemiology: Common intra-articular fracture from trauma, especially in elderly or motor vehicle accidents.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Imaging → Surgical fixation → Rehab

epidemiology: Lateral curvature of the spine. Most cases are idiopathic, especially in adolescent females.
treatment_protocol: Measure Cobb angle → Observe/Brace → Surgery if >40–50°

epidemiology: Popliteal cyst secondary to intra-articular knee pathology (e.g., OA, meniscal tear). Common in adults.

timeline.symptom: Tightness or fullness in knee flexion

important: Ultrasound (to confirm cyst, rule out DVT)

treatment_protocol: Confirm with US → Conservative → Address underlying cause

epidemiology: Orthopedic emergency due to raised pressure in muscle compartments. Common after fractures or crush injury.
treatment_protocol: Suspect clinically → Measure pressure → Immediate fasciotomy

epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory spondyloarthropathy. More common in males (20–40 yrs), HLA-B27 positive.
treatment_protocol: X-ray/MRI → NSAIDs → Biologics if refractory

epidemiology: A joint condition where bone underneath the cartilage of a joint dies due to lack of blood flow. Most common in adolescents.

definitive: Fixation or removal of loose bodies

treatment_protocol: MRI → Conservative → Surgery if detached fragment

epidemiology: Genetic disorder of connective tissue causing brittle bones. Presents in infancy or early childhood.
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Medical therapy → Surgery if needed

epidemiology: Entrapment of posterior tibial nerve in the tarsal tunnel. Similar to carpal tunnel but in foot.
treatment_protocol: NCS → Conservative → Surgery if persistent

epidemiology: Benign bone tumor most commonly seen in adolescents and young adults, especially males.

timeline.symptom: Localized bone pain worse at night

treatment_protocol: X-ray/CT → RFA or excision

epidemiology: Lateral deviation of the great toe with bony prominence over 1st metatarsal head. More common in women.

timeline.symptom: Pain over medial first metatarsophalangeal joint

treatment_protocol: Conservative initially → Surgery if symptomatic deformity

epidemiology: Most common primary bone cancer in children and adolescents. Peak incidence in second decade of life.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy → Neoadjuvant chemo → Resection → Adjuvant chemo

epidemiology: Displacement of femoral head in adolescents (obese boys, ages 10–16).
treatment_protocol: X-ray → Urgent pinning → Monitor contralateral hip

epidemiology: Common in athletes and military recruits due to repetitive stress. 2nd and 3rd metatarsals most affected.
treatment_protocol: Activity restriction → Reimaging → Immobilization if needed

epidemiology: Benign cystic swelling near joints/tendons, most commonly wrist. Common in young adults.
treatment_protocol: Ultrasound → Conservative → Surgery if persistent

epidemiology: Common in children (physiologic), but may persist or be acquired in adults.
treatment_protocol: Conservative initially → Surgical intervention if symptomatic

epidemiology: Common overuse injury in runners and jumpers, typically in middle-aged adults.

timeline.symptom: Pain and stiffness in Achilles tendon

emergency_markers: Sudden severe pain with audible pop (rupture)

treatment_protocol: Conservative first → Surgical if rupture or failed therapy

epidemiology: Most common tarsal bone fracture, usually from high-energy axial load (e.g., fall from height).
treatment_protocol: X-ray/CT → ORIF if displaced → Follow-up for arthritis

epidemiology: Joint infection usually due to hematogenous spread. Most common in children and elderly.
treatment_protocol: Aspiration → IV antibiotics → Washout if no improvement

epidemiology: Degenerative changes of cervical spine. Common in individuals >40 years.
treatment_protocol: Conservative → MRI → Decompression if myelopathy

epidemiology: Most common elbow fracture in children aged 5–10. Caused by fall on outstretched hand.
treatment_protocol: X-ray → Assess neurovascular → Pinning under GA

epidemiology: Overuse injury of patellar tendon, common in athletes involved in jumping sports.

timeline.symptom: Pain with jumping or climbing stairs
Tenderness over inferior pole of patella

treatment_protocol: Conservative → Physical therapy → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Fracture of the upper part of the tibia, common in trauma (e.g. motor vehicle accident, fall).

timeline.symptom: Pain and swelling of the knee

treatment_protocol: X-ray/CT → Classify → Surgical stabilization

epidemiology: Idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children, typically boys aged 4–10.
treatment_protocol: X-ray → Conservative → Surgery if deformity or collapse

epidemiology: Most common cause of heel pain, especially in runners and overweight individuals.
treatment_protocol: Conservative → Injections → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Compression of ulnar nerve at the elbow. Second most common peripheral neuropathy after carpal tunnel.
treatment_protocol: NCS/EMG → Conservative → Surgery if persistent

epidemiology: Bone infection commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Affects children (hematogenous) and adults (post-traumatic or diabetic).
treatment_protocol: Blood work + MRI → Antibiotics → Debridement if necessary

epidemiology: Benign bone tumor affecting children and young adults, commonly long bones like femur and tibia.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → NSAIDs → RFA or excision if refractory

epidemiology: Common in athletes. More prevalent in females. Caused by sudden deceleration or twisting injuries.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Conservative or reconstruction depending on activity level

epidemiology: Common sports-related injury or degenerative in older adults. Medial meniscus more often affected.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Conservative → Surgery if mechanical symptoms persist

epidemiology: Common in older adults and athletes. Due to trauma or degeneration.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Conservative → Surgery if large tear or failure to improve
